data.title: CG Chat Interpreter
data.statement:
You have found hidden meaning in the inane babblings of CG Chat. Write a program to make sense of the madness. This first puzzle introduces the concepts of numeric constants, arithmetic, and stack operations.

NOTE: CG Chat is case insensitive. Also, punctuation is ignored.

<<NICKS>>
Nicknames (nicks) can be at the start of a line in angle brackets ({{< >}}) to indicate the current speaker:

`<jim> Hello!`

Nicks can also be mentioned by a speaker. The mentioned nick is surrounded by asterisks ({{*}}) to emphasize the reference:

`<woody> Get over here, *buzz*!`

<<SET CONTEXT COMMAND>>
Each nick can only talk to one other nick at a time. This is the <<context>> of the conversation:

`<john> Hey, *jude*!`
<<jude>> is <<john>>'s context. Context statements look like:

<{nick}> {flavor text} *{nick}* {flavor text}

Context can also be asserted for the current statement (takes place immediately) if <<*nick*>> occurs at the beginning of the statement. Once context is set for a nick, it persists until a new context is set.

<<CONSTANTS>>
Constants are phrases that represent signed integers, and look like:

{a/an} {adjective(s)} {noun}

The "<<noun>>" (which may not actually be a noun) is from a provided list of "good" and "bad" nouns. Good nouns represent the value {{1}}. Bad nouns represent the value {{-1}}. All words between <<a/an>> and <<noun>> are <<adjectives>>. Each adjective multiplies <<noun>> by {{2}}. So for the phrase:

`a slimy, sad eel`
If <<eel>> is a bad noun, this phrase represents the constant -4: {{2}} x {{2}} x {{-1}} 

<<SPECIAL CONSTANTS>>
Represent the top value from the specified stack:

 - "me" => the speaker's stack
 - "you", "u" => the context's stack
 - <<*{nick}*>> => <<nick>>'s stack (no context change in this situation)

The referenced value is not removed from the corresponding stack.

<<ARITHMETIC CONSTANTS>>
Arithmetic phrases can be used anywhere a {constant} can be used:

 - {constant} squared
 - {constant} and {constant} too => (a + b)
 - {constant} but not {constant} though => (a - b)
 - {constant} by {constant} multiplied => (a * b)

<<ASSIGNMENT COMMAND>>
Words indicating the start of an assignment: "youre", "your", "ur"

This looks like:

{keyword} {flavor text} {constant}

For example:

`<tom> *tina* UR such a good girl. U love u momma.`
This pushes the value 2 onto the top of <<tina>>'s stack

<<STACK COMMANDS>>
 - The keyword <<listen>> duplicates the top value of the context's stack
 - The keyword <<forget>> pops the top value off the context's stack
 - The keyword <<flip>> exchanges the top two values of the context's stack

<<OUTPUT COMMAND>>
Each instance of the following words will pop then print the top value of the context's stack:

 - "tell", "telling" - Print the top value as an integer

<<HINT>>
All tests in this puzzle have one nick who explains what's happening. Pay attention to this.

testCases.title: Syntax: Constants
testCases.testIn:
1 1
hacker
puzzle
25
<__observer>     since I never set a context
<__observer>     all my lines are ignored
<MadKnife> Hi, *[CG]ThisBot*
<__observer>     MK's _context_ is now [CG]TB
<[CG]ThisBot> Hello.
<MadKnife> UR an awesome hacker yet?
<__observer>     "hacker" is a _good_ word
<__observer>     so "an awesome hacker" is a _constant_
<__observer>     since there is one _adjective_
<__observer>     the value is 2 x 1 = 2
<__observer>     the keyword "ur" pushes 2 onto [CG]TB
<[CG]ThisBot> I'm getting better all the time.
<MadKnife> I'll tell you how to be an awesome hacker.
<__observer>     the keyword "tell" pops then
<__observer>     prints the top of [CG]TB
<[CG]ThisBot> Oh really?
<MadKnife> You're still stuck on a silly, pointless puzzle.
<__observer>     "puzzle" is a _bad_ word
<__observer>     with 2 _adjectives_, the phrase
<__observer>     "a silly pointless puzzle" pushes
<__observer>     2 x 2 x -1 = -4 onto [CG]TB
<MadKnife> I'm telling the truth.
<__observer>     "telling" is another form of "tell"
<__observer>     pop then print
<MadKnife> Play CSB. Then you'll be awesome.

testCases.title: Syntax: Constants
testCases.testIn:
1 1
lightning
thunder
5
<Mark> Hi, *Frank*
<Mark> You're as flashy as a lightning strike.
<Mark> That's what I'm telling you.
<Mark> You're not a noisy thunder clap.
<Mark> Otherwise, I would tell you.

testCases.title: Syntax: Context
testCases.testIn:
1 0
coder

38
<[CG]JustAxe> hi *TearyMoon*
<__observer>     [CG]JA _context_ -> TM
<[CG]JustAxe> what you doin?
<TearyMoon> Hi *[CG]JustAxe*
<__observer>     TM _context_ -> [CG]JA
<TearyMoon> Working on csb
<[CG]JustAxe> dude, ur a real good coder
<__observer>     "a real good coder" -> 4
<__observer>     "ur" -> push
<__observer>     TM stack: [ 4 ]
<TearyMoon> Thanks, man!
<TearyMoon> You too!
<TearyMoon> You're a great coder, yourself
<__observer>     "a great coder" -> 2
<__observer>     "youre" -> push
<__observer>     [CG]JA stack: [ 2 ]
<[CG]JustAxe> you hear that, *SoftCounterKitcheh*?
<__observer>     [CG]JA _context_ -> SCK
<TearyMoon> *SoftCounterKitcheh*, you're a really excellent coder too!
<__observer>     since the reference to SCK is
<__observer>     at the beginning of the line,
<__observer>     the context is effective
<__observer>     immediately for this statement
<__observer>     SCK stack: [ 4 ]
<SoftCounterKitcheh> Awe, that's so sweet, *TearyMoon*!
<__observer>     SCK _context_ -> TM
<SoftCounterKitcheh> Tell me more!
<__observer>     "tell" -> print int
<__observer>     print "4"
<__observer>     TM stack: [ ]
<SoftCounterKitcheh> *[CG]JustAxe*, you going to tell me something nice too?
<__observer>     since the reference to [CG]JA is
<__observer>     at the beginning of the line,
<__observer>     the context is effective
<__observer>     immediately for this statement
<__observer>     "tell" -> print int
<__observer>     print "2"
<__observer>     [CG]JA stack: [ ]

testCases.title: Syntax: Context
testCases.testIn:
1 0
coder

13
<sam> hi *tom*
<sam> what you doin?
<tom> Hi *sam*
<tom> Working on csb
<sam> dude, ur a real good coder
<tom> Thanks, man!
<tom> You too!
<tom> You're a mighty fine coder, yourself
<sam> you hear that, *kim*?
<tom> *kim*, you're a really excellent coder too!
<kim> Awe, that's so sweet, *tom*!
<kim> Tell me more!
<kim> *sam*, you going to tell me something nice too?

testCases.title: Syntax: Addition
testCases.testIn:
1 1
apple
core
17
<MrRandomNum> hey *[CG]SexyApple*
<__lurker>     MRN -> [CG]SA
<[CG]SexyApple> What's up?
<MrRandomNum> I was just contemplating...
<MrRandomNum> I think your a bright, shiny, juicy apple and a tough core too.
<__lurker>     "a bright shiny juicy apple" -> 2 x 2 x 2 x 1 = 8
<__lurker>     "a tough core" -> 2 x -1 = -2
<__lurker>     the keywords "and" and "too" indicate addition
<__lurker>     "8 and -2 too" -> 8 + -2 = 6
<__lurker>     "your 6" -> push 6
<__lurker>     [CG]SA -> [ 6 ]
<[CG]SexyApple> Wow. That's deep.
<[CG]SexyApple> And a bit random, too.
<MrRandomNum> I tell it like it is.
<__lurker>     "tell" -> print
<__lurker>     print "6"
<__lurker>     [CG]SA -> [ ]

testCases.title: Syntax: Addition
testCases.testIn:
1 1
apple
core
3
<Joe> hey *Hannah*
<Joe> I think your a bright, shiny apple and a tough core too.
<Joe> I tell it like it is.

testCases.title: Syntax: Subtraction
testCases.testIn:
1 0
meme

16
<RickyMoppet> You here, *JayBeEmmy*?
<__lurker>     RM -> JBE
<JayBeEmmy> I'm here, *RickyMoppet*.
<__lurker>     JBE -> RM
<RickyMoppet> Your nick is reminiscent of an old, boring, confusing meme, but not a bad meme, though.
<__lurker>     "an old boring confusing meme" -> 2 x 2 x 2 x 1 = 8
<__lurker>     "a bad meme" -> 2 x 1 = 2
<__lurker>     the keywords "but not" and "though" indicate subtraction
<__lurker>     "8 but not 2 though" -> 8 - 2 = 6
<__lurker>     "your {extra words ignored} 6" -> push 6
<__lurker>     JBE -> [ 6 ]
<RickyMoppet> Tell me what you think of that?
<__lurker>     "tell" -> print
<__lurker>     print "6"
<__lurker>     JBE -> [ ]
<JayBeEmmy> I think I'm confused.

testCases.title: Syntax: Subtraction
testCases.testIn:
1 1
apple
core
3
<Joe> hey *Hannah*
<Joe> I think your a bright, shiny apple but not a tough core though.
<Joe> I tell it like it is.

testCases.title: Syntax: Multiplication
testCases.testIn:
2 0
lines times

18
<SeeSam> Hi all
<Bub> Hello *SeeSam*.
<SeeSam> Hey, *Bub*, can you help me with something?
<__bigbrother>     SS -> B
<Bub> I'd love to, but
<Bub> your code is always like a tragic mess of lines by a thousand times multiplied
<__bigbrother>     "a tragic mess of lines" -> 2 x 2 x 2 x 1 = 8
<__bigbrother>     "a thousand times" -> 2 x 1 = 2
<__bigbrother>     the keywords "by" and "multiplied" indicate multiplication
<__bigbrother>     "8 by 2 multiplied" -> 8 x 2 = 16
<__bigbrother>     "your {extra words ignored} 16" -> push 16
<__bigbrother>     SS -> [ 16 ]
<Bub> Sorry, but I had to tell you.
<__bigbrother>     "tell" -> print
<__bigbrother>     print "16"
<__bigbrother>     SS -> [ ]
<SeeSam> Sigh.
<SeeSam> I get it.

testCases.title: Syntax: Multiplication
testCases.testIn:
2 0
characters times

4
<Tina> Hello *Nick*.
<Nick> Hi *Tina*. Can you help me with something?
<Tina> your code is always like a tragic mess of characters by a hundred, million times multiplied
<Tina> Sorry, but I had to tell you.

testCases.title: Syntax: Squares
testCases.testIn:
0 1

problem
13
<SeeTheRazor> Hey! Any CG around?
<[CG]JayPullTongue> I'm here, *SeeTheRazor*
<__nobody>     [CG]JPT -> STR
<SeeTheRazor> *[CG]JayPullTongue*, your site has a really big problem squared!
<__nobody>     STR -> [CG]JPT
<__nobody>     "a really big problem" -> -4
<__nobody>     "-4 squared" -> 16
<__nobody>     "your ... 16" -> [CG]JPT -> [ 16 ]
<[CG]JayPullTongue> Sounds serious!
<SeeTheRazor> Should I tell you about it?
<__nobody>     "tell" -> print "16"
<__nobody>     [GC]JPT -> [ ]
<[CG]JayPullTongue> Shoot!

testCases.title: Syntax: Squares
testCases.testIn:
0 1

monkey
4

<Mary> You're a bald monkey squared!

<Mary> Tell me what you think of that!

testCases.title: Syntax: "me" and "you"
testCases.testIn:
1 1
developer
baby
28
<aGate> *MoGas*
<__fanboi>     AG -> MG
<MoGas> I'm here, *aGate*.
<__fanboi>     MG -> AG
<aGate> You seen my CB?
<aGate> UR AI fell down like a squealing baby!
<__fanboi>     "a squealing baby" -> -2
<__fanboi>     "ur ... -2" -> MG -> [ -2 ]
<MoGas> Haven't seen it
<MoGas> But I believe it
<MoGas> You're a very highly skilled AI developer.
<__fanboi>     "a very highly skilled AI developer" -> 16
<__fanboi>     "youre 16" -> AG -> [ 16 ]
<aGate> Yeah, but you're you! And a monster of a developer too!
<__fanboi>     "you" -> Top of MG -> [ -2 ]
<__fanboi>     "a monster of a developer" -> 8
<__fanboi>     "-2 and 8 too" -> -2 + 8 = 6
<__fanboi>     "youre 6" -> MG -> [ -2 6 ]
<aGate> You're like as good as me squared!
<__fanboi>     "me" -> 16
<__fanboi>     "16 squared" -> 256
<__fanboi>     "youre ... 256" -> MG -> [ -2 6 256 ]
<aGate> I can't tell you how excited I am.
<__fanboi>     "tell" -> print "256"
<__fanboi>     MG -> [ -2 6 ]
<aGate> Can't tell you.
<__fanboi>     "tell" -> print "6"
<__fanboi>     MG -> [ -2 ]

testCases.title: Syntax: "me" and "you"

1 1
developer
baby

<Hank> Can't tell you.

testCases.title: Syntax: Nick references
testCases.testIn:
0 2

complainer jerk
29
<RoyL> *NoMan*
<__harvey>     RL -> NM
<NoMan> What's up, *RoyL*?
<__harvey>     NM -> RL
<RoyL> I was just talking with *[CG]VonFlagPole*
<__harvey>     RL -> [CG]VFP
<RoyL> and he said you're an annoying complainer.
<__harvey>     "an annoying complainer" -> -2
<__harvey>     "youre -2" -> [CG]VFP -> [ -2 ]
<NoMan> Dude, ur more of a complainer than I am!
<__harvey>     "a complainer" -> -1
<__harvey>     "ur ... -1" -> RL -> [ -1 ]
<[CG]VonFlagPole> *NoMan*, youre at least as bad as *RoyL*, but not a complete jerk, though.
<__harvey>     [CG]VFP -> NM (immediate)
<__harvey>     ref to nick "RoyL" -> -1 (no context change)
<__harvey>     "a complete jerk" -> -2
<__harvey>     "-1 but not -2 though" -> -1 - -2 = 1
<__harvey>     "youre ... 1" -> NM -> [ 1 ]
<[CG]VonFlagPole> I'm sorry to have to be the one to tell you.
<__harvey>     "tell" -> print "1"
<__harvey>     NM -> [ ]
<RoyL> I have no problem telling him.
<__harvey>     "telling" -> print "-2"
<__harvey>     [CG]VFP -> [ ]
<[CG]VonFlagPole> *RoyL*, you otoh are a complete jerk.
<__harvey>     [CG]VFP -> RL
<[CG]VonFlagPole> And I have no problem telling you that.
<__harvey>     "telling" -> print "-1"
<__harvey>     RL -> [ ]

testCases.title: Syntax: Nick references
testCases.testIn:
1 1
jerk
complainer
10
<Tammy> *Sammy*
<Sammy> What's up, *Tammy*?
<Tammy> I was just talking with *Jazzy*
<Tammy> and he said you're an annoying complainer.
<Sammy> Dude, ur more of a complainer than I am!
<Jazzy> *Sammy*, youre at least as bad as *Tammy*, but not a complete jerk, though.
<Jazzy> I'm sorry to have to be the one to tell you.
<Tammy> I have no problem telling him.
<Jazzy> *Tammy*, you otoh are a complete jerk.
<Jazzy> And I have no problem telling you that.

testCases.title: Syntax: pop, dup, flip
testCases.testIn:
1 1
flashlight
squeegee
31
<SuperPinkMunk> *Rekkur*, your like a big flaming squeegee!
<__imnothere>     SPM -> R (immediate)
<__imnothere>     "a big flaming squeegee" -> -4
<__imnothere>     "your -4" -> R -> [ -4 ]
<SuperPinkMunk> you listen to me!
<__imnothere>     "listen" -> duplicate top of R
<__imnothere>     R -> [ -4 -4 ]
<SuperPinkMunk> your a bright, shining flashlight in the darkness.
<__imnothere>     "a bright, shining flashlight" -> 4
<__imnothere>     "your 4" -> R -> [ -4 -4 4 ]
<SuperPinkMunk> don't flip out on me.
<__imnothere>     "flip" -> exchange top 2 of R
<__imnothere>     R -> [ -4 4 -4 ]
<SuperPinkMunk> your a squeegee and a flashlight too.
<__imnothere>     "a squeegee" -> -1
<__imnothere>     "a flashlight" -> 1
<__imnothere>     "-1 and 1 too" -> 0
<__imnothere>     "your 0"
<__imnothere>     R -> [ -4 4 -4 0 ]
<SuperPinkMunk> don't forget it.
<__imnothere>     "forget" -> pop top of R
<__imnothere>     R -> [ -4 4 -4 ]
<SuperPinkMunk> I'm telling you.
<__imnothere>     "telling" -> print "-4"
<__imnothere>     R -> [ -4 4 ]
<SuperPinkMunk> That's what I'll tell you.
<__imnothere>     "tell" -> print "4"
<__imnothere>     R -> [ -4 ]
<SuperPinkMunk> I'm telling you.
<__imnothere>     "telling" -> print "-4"
<__imnothere>     R -> [ ]

testCases.title: Syntax: pop, dup, flip
testCases.testIn:
1 1
tophat
fungus
9
<Helen> *Chad*, your like a nasty fungus.
<Helen> you listen to me!
<Helen> your a new tophat.
<Helen> don't flip out on me.
<Helen> your a fungus and a tophat too.
<Helen> don't forget it.
<Helen> I'm telling you.
<Helen> That's what I'll tell you.
<Helen> I'm telling you.

testCases.title: Syntax: Nested arithmetic
testCases.testIn:
2 1
squid basket
partridge
17
<Angst> *PbjIsGood* ur more fun than a blind squid and a stunned partridge squared too!
<__somebody>     A -> PIG (immediate)
<__somebody>     "a blind squid" -> 2
<__somebody>     "a stunned partridge" -> -2
<__somebody>     "-2 squared" -> 4
<__somebody>     "2 and 4 too" -> 6
<__somebody>     "ur ... 6" -> PIG -> [ 6 ]
<Angst> ur like u and u too but not a hand made basket squared though
<__somebody>     "u" -> 6 (twice)
<__somebody>     "6 and 6 too" -> 12
<__somebody>     "a hand made basket" -> 4
<__somebody>     "4 squared" -> 16
<__somebody>     "12 but not 16 though" -> -4
<__somebody>     "ur ... -4" -> PIG -> [ 6 -4 ]
<Angst> u hear what I tell u?
<__somebody>     "tell" -> print "-4"
<__somebody>     PIG -> [ 6 ]

testCases.title: Quiz
testCases.testIn:
5 2
batman late times filth coder
dweeb troll
92
<CaptainCocktail_61ac> *FlamingImp_5f5d*
<pray_or_run>     CC -> FI
<CaptainCocktail_61ac> i am batman.
<CaptainCocktail_61ac> your a pathetic imitation of batman, and a dweeb too, *FlamingImp_5f5d*.
<pray_or_run>     "a pathetic imitation of batman" -> 8
<pray_or_run>     "a dweeb" -> -1
<pray_or_run>     "8 and -1 too" -> 8 + -1 = 7
<pray_or_run>     FI -> [ 7 ]
<FlamingImp_5f5d> Hey *TheRustyLady_89e6*!
<pray_or_run>     FI -> TRL
<FlamingImp_5f5d> You're actually a teeny tiny bit late, but not a lot late though.
<pray_or_run>     "a teeny tiny bit late" -> 8
<pray_or_run>     "a lot late" -> 2
<pray_or_run>     "8 but not 2 though" -> 8 - 2 = 6
<pray_or_run>     TRL -> [ 6 ]
<TheRustyLady_89e6> Late for what?
<CaptainCocktail_61ac> *TheRustyLady_89e6* your actually you squared!
<pray_or_run>     CC -> TRL
<pray_or_run>     "you" -> 6 (top of TRL)
<pray_or_run>     "6 squared" -> 6 ^ 2 = 36
<pray_or_run>     TRL -> [ 6 36 ]
<TheRustyLady_89e6> What does that even mean, *CaptainCocktail_61ac*??
<pray_or_run>     TRL -> CC
<TheRustyLady_89e6> I thought you're a beginner, just like me and *FlamingImp_5f5d* too?
<pray_or_run>     "a beginner" -> beginner is neither _good_ nor _bad
<pray_or_run>     so it's not a _constant_
<pray_or_run>     "me and FI too" -> 36 + 7 = 43
<pray_or_run>     CC -> [ 43 ]
<FlamingImp_5f5d> Yeah, *CaptainCocktail_61ac*!
<pray_or_run>     FI -> CC
<FlamingImp_5f5d> Tell us!
<pray_or_run>     print "43"
<pray_or_run>     CC -> [ ]
<FlamingImp_5f5d> you're not as nice as me, and an immature troll too!
<pray_or_run>     "me and an immature troll too" -> 7 + -2 = 5
<pray_or_run>     CC -> [ 5 ]
<TheRustyLady_89e6> YOU'RE *CaptainCocktail_61ac* squared! :-P
<pray_or_run>     "CC squared" -> 5 ^ 2 = 25
<pray_or_run>     CC -> [ 5 25 ]
<TheRustyLady_89e6> whatever that means...
<TheRustyLady_89e6> i'm ready to listen
<pray_or_run>     "listen" -> dup
<pray_or_run>     CC -> [ 5 25 25 ]
<TheRustyLady_89e6> please tell us!
<pray_or_run>     print "25"
<pray_or_run>     CC -> [ 5 25 ]
<CaptainCocktail_61ac> *FlamingImp_5f5d*, UR JUST LIKE ME
<pray_or_run>     CC -> FI
<pray_or_run>     "UR ME" -> 25
<pray_or_run>     FI -> [ 7 25 ]
<CaptainCocktail_61ac> except ur me by a hundred thousand million times multiplied.
<pray_or_run>     "me by a hundred thousand million times multiplied" -> 25 x 8 = 200
<pray_or_run>     FI -> [ 7 25 200 ]
<TheRustyLady_89e6> Ha!
<TheRustyLady_89e6> *FlamingImp_5f5d*, listen to that!
<pray_or_run>     FI -> [ 7 25 200 200 ]
<TheRustyLady_89e6> Boy did he tell you, *FlamingImp_5f5d*!
<pray_or_run>     print "200"
<pray_or_run>     FI -> [ 7 25 200 ]
<CaptainCocktail_61ac> *TheRustyLady_89e6* YOU listen to ME!
<pray_or_run>     CC -> TRL
<pray_or_run>     TRL -> [ 6 36 36 ]
<CaptainCocktail_61ac> Your code is like a steaming, stinking, putrid, pile of filth!
<pray_or_run>     "a steaming stinking putrid pile of filth" -> 32
<pray_or_run>     TRL -> [ 6 36 36 32 ]
<CaptainCocktail_61ac> *FlamingImp_5f5d* ur code is just like *TheRustyLady_89e6*
<pray_or_run>     "ur TRL" -> 32
<pray_or_run>     FI -> [ 7 25 200 32 ]
<CaptainCocktail_61ac> u listen
<pray_or_run>     FI -> [ 7 25 200 32 32 ]
<CaptainCocktail_61ac> Boy did I tell you!
<pray_or_run>     print "32"
<pray_or_run>     FI -> [ 7 25 200 32 ]
<CaptainCocktail_61ac> *TheRustyLady_89e6* dont you forget it
<pray_or_run>     CC -> TRL
<CaptainCocktail_61ac> your you by a truckloadof filth multiplied, and a spoonfulof filth too
<pray_or_run>     "you by a truckloadof filth multiplied" -> 36 x 2 = 72
<pray_or_run>     "72 and a spoonfulof filth too" -> 72 + 2 = 74
<pray_or_run>     TRL -> [ 6 36 36 74 ]
<CaptainCocktail_61ac> tell me what you think of that!
<pray_or_run>     print "74"
<pray_or_run>     TRL -> [ 6 36 36 ]
<CaptainCocktail_61ac> *TheRustyLady_89e6*, ur as bad as *FlamingImp_5f5d*
<pray_or_run>     TRL -> [ 6 36 36 32 ]
<FlamingImp_5f5d> Ignore that troll, *TheRustyLady_89e6*.
<pray_or_run>     FI -> TRL

In this instance, the context is changed immediately for that line (and all subsequent lines) and another command <<can>> be given on that same line.

data.inputDescription:
<<Line 1:>> Two space-separated integers, [[numGood]] and [[numBad]] indicating the number of "good" and "bad" nouns that will be declared.
<<Line 2:>> A space-separated list of [[numGood]] "good" nouns. (Blank line if [[numGood]] == 0)
<<Line 3:>> A space-separated list of [[numBad]] "bad" nouns. (Blank line if [[numBad]] == 0)
<<Line 4:>> An integer, [[numLines]], indicating the number of lines in the chat transcript
<<Next [[numLines]] lines:>> The chat transcript to be interpreted

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

You have found hidden meaning in the inane babblings of CG Chat. Write a program to make sense of the madness. This first puzzle introduces the concepts of numeric constants, arithmetic, and stack operations.

NOTE: CG Chat is case insensitive. Also, punctuation is ignored.

NICKS
Nicknames (nicks) can be at the start of a line in angle brackets (< >) to indicate the current speaker:

<jim> Hello!


Nicks can also be mentioned by a speaker. The mentioned nick is surrounded by asterisks (*) to emphasize the reference:

<woody> Get over here, *buzz*!


SET CONTEXT COMMAND
Each nick can only talk to one other nick at a time. This is the context of the conversation:

<john> Hey, *jude*!

jude is john's context. Context statements look like:

<{nick}> {flavor text} *{nick}* {flavor text}

Context can also be asserted for the current statement (takes place immediately) if *nick* occurs at the beginning of the statement. Once context is set for a nick, it persists until a new context is set.

CONSTANTS
Constants are phrases that represent signed integers, and look like:

{a/an} {adjective(s)} {noun}

The "noun" (which may not actually be a noun) is from a provided list of "good" and "bad" nouns. Good nouns represent the value 1. Bad nouns represent the value -1. All words between a/an and noun are adjectives. Each adjective multiplies noun by 2. So for the phrase:

a slimy, sad eel

If eel is a bad noun, this phrase represents the constant -4: 2 x 2 x -1

SPECIAL CONSTANTS
Represent the top value from the specified stack:

- "me" => the speaker's stack
- "you", "u" => the context's stack
- *{nick}* => nick's stack (no context change in this situation)

The referenced value is not removed from the corresponding stack.

ARITHMETIC CONSTANTS
Arithmetic phrases can be used anywhere a {constant} can be used:

- {constant} squared
- {constant} and {constant} too => (a + b)
- {constant} but not {constant} though => (a - b)
- {constant} by {constant} multiplied => (a * b)

ASSIGNMENT COMMAND
Words indicating the start of an assignment: "youre", "your", "ur"

This looks like:

{keyword} {flavor text} {constant}

For example:

<tom> *tina* UR such a good girl. U love u momma.

This pushes the value 2 onto the top of tina's stack

STACK COMMANDS
- The keyword listen duplicates the top value of the context's stack
- The keyword forget pops the top value off the context's stack
- The keyword flip exchanges the top two values of the context's stack

OUTPUT COMMAND
Each instance of the following words will pop then print the top value of the context's stack:

- "tell", "telling" - Print the top value as an integer

HINT
All tests in this puzzle have one nick who explains what's happening. Pay attention to this.
Input
Line 1: Two space-separated integers, numGood and numBad indicating the number of "good" and "bad" nouns that will be declared.
Line 2: A space-separated list of numGood "good" nouns. (Blank line if numGood == 0)
Line 3: A space-separated list of numBad "bad" nouns. (Blank line if numBad == 0)
Line 4: An integer, numLines, indicating the number of lines in the chat transcript
Next numLines lines: The chat transcript to be interpreted
Output
The output of the program
Constraints
Each line may contain multiple constants, but will only contain a single command. The exception to this is if a context change occurs as the first word in a line. In this instance, the context is changed immediately for that line (and all subsequent lines) and another command can be given on that same line.
Example
Input
1 1
hacker
puzzle
25
<__observer>     since I never set a context
<__observer>     all my lines are ignored
<MadKnife> Hi, *[CG]ThisBot*
<__observer>     MK's _context_ is now [CG]TB
<[CG]ThisBot> Hello.
<MadKnife> UR an awesome hacker yet?
<__observer>     "hacker" is a _good_ word
<__observer>     so "an awesome hacker" is a _constant_
<__observer>     since there is one _adjective_
<__observer>     the value is 2 x 1 = 2
<__observer>     the keyword "ur" pushes 2 onto [CG]TB
<[CG]ThisBot> I'm getting better all the time.
<MadKnife> I'll tell you how to be an awesome hacker.
<__observer>     the keyword "tell" pops then
<__observer>     prints the top of [CG]TB
<[CG]ThisBot> Oh really?
<MadKnife> You're still stuck on a silly, pointless puzzle.
<__observer>     "puzzle" is a _bad_ word
<__observer>     with 2 _adjectives_, the phrase
<__observer>     "a silly pointless puzzle" pushes
<__observer>     2 x 2 x -1 = -4 onto [CG]TB
<MadKnife> I'm telling the truth.
<__observer>     "telling" is another form of "tell"
<__observer>     pop then print
<MadKnife> Play CSB. Then you'll be awesome.
Output
2-4
